a lonely union
 +++ something that makes me happy about this marriage, despite how upsetting it is, is the thought that they can bring each other companionship and give each other some sort of unique strength despite their abusers’ attempts to limit it

summary: Esther Dot's answer to Did Daenerys Targaryen fall under ploy of Sansa Stark by taking extreme measures against people of King's...
title: Esther Dot's answer to Did Daenerys Targaryen fall under ploy of Sansa Stark by taking extreme measures against people of King's Landing? Why does Sansa want to see Daenerys fail? - Quora
description:
“Did Daenerys Targaryen fall under ploy of Sansa Stark by taking extreme measures against people of King’s Landing? Why does Sansa want to see Daenerys fail?”

Dany’s actions in King’s Landing are wildly misinterpreted. Dany is obsessed with urban planning, and this was step one of implementing her plans for a better KL.

Step 1: burn everything to hell for the good of the people

Step 2: continue step 1 until it doesn’t feel good anymore

Step 3: when you run out of shit to burn, find a new city!

Maybe there’s a missing element in her process, but you get the idea. She had good intentions and that’s all that matters. I meant that as a joke, and yet, it’s a pretty good way to describe her actions everywhere she goes. She disrupts and destroys what is, but, she never has a plan, a way to move past the destruction and build something good or lasting. Dany doesn’t have foresight. She has (what she believes to be) righteous anger.

In s6 during the siege of Meereen, Tyrion asks if she has a plan and Dany’s plan consists of crucifying the masters and “returning their cities to the dirt.” Tyrion responds by telling her of her father’s plan for KL.

Tyrion: “He would have burned every one of the citizens, the loyal ones and the traitors. Every man, woman, and child. That’s why Jaime killed him.”

Dany: “This is entirely different.”

Tyrion: “We’re talking about destroying cities. It’s not entirely different.”

I think the idea is that having the power to unilaterally decide a city’s fate is a power no one should have because you will convince yourself each time you do it that it is right until it always seems right to do it. Now, Tyrion admits in 8x06 that in general it was evil men who died when Dany went on the warpath, but if you do an open minded rewatch of Dany’s scenes, I think you’ll realize her actions seem justifiable because she justifies them, not because they are objectively the right or wise thing to do. Flip the script, think about it from a different perspective. I do that a bit at the beginning of this answer to give you an idea of what I mean

Esther Dot’s answer to What would you have done to make Dany’s fall from grace different? We mostly agree that burning King’s Landing was too far (and too rushed), so how would you have done it as a writer?

Now, back to finding someone else to blame for Dany burning things. If we’re to be brutally honest, the people in King’s Landing had legs, they should have run faster. Shame on them for making Dany look bad by being highly flammable. No? Ok, let’s find someone else to blame. Ah! Cersei! Yes, she tricked Dany into burning the city by…ringing the bells? Surrendering? Making burning the city unnecessary? Darn. That leaves us with Sansa. And therefore I will have to reintroduce the theory that Sansa is a warg who took control of Drogon and burned KL against Dany’s will. That’s not a real theory? Now it is!

Fine! No dragon warging for Sansa. But, don’t worry. We will blame Sansa for this. Let me find a way…ah, ok! If Sansa had never whispered the idea of a bonfire in Dany’s ear, if she had never secured the dragons to make it possible, if she had never convinced Dany that the Iron Throne was hers and had been stolen from her family, if Sansa had never told Dany to take what is hers with “fire and blood”, if Sansa had never amassed an army for the sole purpose of conquering a continent, if Sansa had never worshiped Dany, feeding into her savior complex (like Jorah, Tyrion, every man Dany ever encounters…), if Sansa had never tried to use Dany as a means of revenge and wanted her to be ruthless and vicious (Olenna, Yara, Ellaria), than Dany would have never done anything morally ambiguous, objectionable, or cruel. Wait, what’s this now? Dany has been burning people alive since s1? WTH Sansa?! Damn. My girl’s power is unparalleled!

Do I really think that Sansa spreading the truth about Jon’s identity is the reason Dany burned KL? No. She wanted to do this for seasons. She mentioned this before she ever met Sansa. Back in s7 Dany said she was going to burn the Red Keep and Tyrion said “we’ve discussed this.” What did he mean? Why was he worried? Scroll back up to those quotes from s6. Burning any part of KL had the potential to set off the wildfire caches that he told her about. Not only that, he warned her about burning cities at all. As in, maybe, she shouldn’t do it at all. Tyrion and Jon both work to make her behave in a humane manner in s7 and s8, but to no avail. This is who Dany has always warned us she was. The dragons just gave her the power to follow her natural instinct. Why do I say that? In s2 Dany said that when her dragons were grown she would “lay waste to armies and burn cities to the ground.”

So yes, in 8x05 Dany blames Sansa for her burning Varys, but you know who she blames next? Jon. She can tell Jon doesn’t love her anymore so she says, “fear it is” and then she goes and burns King’s Landing. Is it Jon’s fault? NO. Dany can blame anyone she wants, but just because she tries to pin mass murder on other people doesn’t mean we need to buy it, especially when other people have been fighting to preserve life all along.

I mean, I get it. We all have that instinctive “but is burning people alive really bad?” reaction, but yeah, it’s always been bad, Dany has always done it, and no matter how Dany rationalizes it, it’s still evil. It’s still Dany’s fault. How do I know? Cuz Dany is on the dragon roasting people, not Sansa.

And Sansa wants to see Dany “fail” because Dany is a tyrant. That’s a fair name for someone who thinks she needs to kill everyone who doesn’t agree with her. Dany claimed to be a liberator, but the only thing she consistently offered was death. Wanting someone like that to fail makes you the good guy.

blog.title: They're good dogs Brent
blog.description: I'm not worried. I tend to bounce back.

summary: Jaime’s trial at Winterfell makes no sense if you think about it, not the part of Brienne having to speak up of him to Sansa...
body:
Jaime’s trial at Winterfell makes no sense if you think about it, not the part of Brienne having to speak up of him to Sansa anyway. Even though I love watching it, it’s really absurd that at this point Sansa doesn’t know about Jaime’s involvement in her rescue. If I recall correctly, the reason the Hound didn’t trust Brienne when they crossed paths was because Oathkeeper and its belt was filled with Lannisters symbols. He thought she would only harm Arya so he fought her. Now, are we supposed to believe that during this whole time Sansa didn’t notice or care to ask why would she wear such symbols? 

Imagine the trial again but Sansa knows this. She’s angry of course, she wants him to pay but we could see she’s also conflicted, she avoids looking at Brienne. Then Brienne steps up, talks about Jaime’s honor and how he saved her from rape. Sansa and Brienne share heavy looks, almost as if Brienne is pleading with her to acknowledge what she knows he did for her, giving her the choice. Sansa resigned tells the room he was the reason she was there, to begin with. Then just the good old you vouch for him? you would fight beside him? I trust you with my life…

I don’t know that would have shown the intricacies of the story and of the characters, how they are all so deeply connected and you know THAT THEY ACTUALLY TALK TO EACH OTHER!

Jaime’s trial at Winterfell makes no sense if you think about it, not the part of Brienne having to speak up of him to Sansa anyway. Even though I love watching it, it’s really absurd that at this point Sansa doesn’t know about Jaime’s involvement in her rescue. If I recall correctly, the reason the Hound didn’t trust Brienne when they crossed paths was because Oathkeeper and its belt was filled with Lannisters symbols. He thought she would only harm Arya so he fought her. Now, are we supposed to believe that during this whole time Sansa didn’t notice or care to ask why would she wear such symbols? 

Imagine the trial again but Sansa knows this. She’s angry of course, she wants him to pay but we could see she’s also conflicted, she avoids looking at Brienne. Then Brienne steps up, talks about Jaime’s honor and how he saved her from rape. Sansa and Brienne share heavy looks, almost as if Brienne is pleading with her to acknowledge what she knows he did for her, giving her the choice. Sansa resigned tells the room he was the reason she was there, to begin with. Then just the good old you vouch for him? you would fight beside him? I trust you with my life…

I don’t know that would have shown the intricacies of the story and of the characters, how they are all so deeply connected and you know THAT THEY ACTUALLY TALK TO EACH OTHER!

summary: Are you happy with Sansa's ending?
question: Are you happy with Sansa's ending?
answer:
Honestly? I have mixed feelings about it. Like she totally deserved to be Queen in the North so I’m happy about her progress there? But at the same time I don’t like that she’s all alone. Her family left her and even Brienne and Pod are in the South in the end. She has no one.

Also they wrote Sansa as very weary/jealous of Dany yet they never explained why? That was a bit confusing for me. Like yes she didn’t trust her and she had every right not to. Dany road into Winterfell with a butt load of entitlement so it makes sense that Sansa wouldn’t like this person who comes into her home thinking she can just take over when Sansa has kept it running.

But all those snide remarks? The conversation with Jon? The feast after they beat the knight king…I mean it was clear as day she was jealous. But they never explained why she felt that way? So that was a little off putting lol.

But I mean yeah like I’m so happy she survived and Sophie killed it with the scenes she had. I just think the writing could have been better.

summary: Alright Cori give us the tea lol what did you think of the GOT finale?
question: Alright Cori give us the tea lol what did you think of the GOT finale?
answer:
Haha wow this answer is super late because I’ve been avoiding my personal tumblr for weeks? Also the tea haha. I’ll give you the coffee - :P 

I’m gonna be brief here because we’ll it’s been a while since the finale lol. There were some endings I thought season 8 did really well aka Jorah and Theon. I thought both characters had a really good arc and their ending was emotional and with Theon he got that redemption and I sobbed a bit.

And yes, I got Queen in the North Sansa which is nothing to scoff about. BUUUTTTTT it was lacking lol. Look there were a lot of things that didn’t make sense in season 8. They completely DESTROYED Jon’s character in service of Daenery’s (Which I know is an unpopular opinion) but it’s MY opinion.

Jon’s parentage reveal literally did nothing, which was disappointing as hell. Sansa who has been trying to keep her family together gets to be queen in the north ALL BY HERSELF no family in sight. Not even Brienne and Pod were with her. She was alone, which sucks.

Dany should have died in the fight at Winterfell to preserve her character and so all those people in Kings Landing wouldn’t have died. Anyone who has been watching this show since S1 had to have seen she was becoming the villian. Like it wasn’t subtle at all LoL. They dropped massive hits from S3 onward but the fandom likes to forget all that - which again is fine. Perspectives and opinions are subjective.

But yeah, I wasn’t a huge fan of the ending. I’m glad my favs survived but I expected more of something they spent eons shooting. The acting was good - the writing though was terrible. It is what it is. At least we still have the books? [ Which I just started on Audible btw. ] So I’m only on the first book lol. Hopefully GRR Martin’s ending will be better.

summary: Save Me by Noah Kahan definitely could be considered a Sanrion song.  Particularly from Tyrion’s POV towards Sansa (especially...
body:
Save Me by Noah Kahan definitely could be considered a Sanrion song. 

Particularly from Tyrion’s POV towards Sansa (especially in the context of certain fanfictions like ‘The Lone Lion’ and ‘The Bastard of Winterfell’), or also from Sansa to Tyrion (for some of the post-season 8 fanfictions like ‘we’ve been together for as long as I remember (but we only make love in the spring)’). 

Just take a look at the lyrics:

“I’m so passive, too sarcastic
Shut you out just out of habit
I don’t know
So I spent five months out here treading water
Now I wonder why you bothered
I don’t know
Let me go

Why do you keep reaching for my hand?
Do you see something I can’t?
Why do you try to save me?
This fate is well deserved
I only make things worse
Why do you try to save me?

Have I served my sentence?
Learned my lesson?
Healed those wounds from my indiscretions?
I don’t know
Am I still so selfish?
Exile ended?
What do you see in my misdirections?
I don’t know
Let me go

Why do you keep reaching for my hand?
Do you see something I can’t?
Why do you try to save me?
This fate is well deserved
I only make things worse
Why do you try to save me?

And sometimes I pray
That maybe I will change
Into who you think I am

Why do you keep reaching for my hand?
Do you see something I can’t?
Why do you try to save me?
This fate is well deserved
I only make things worse
Why do you try to save me?
Why do you try to save me?”

summary: One of the things that I think game of thrones should be applauded for is how they presented the Stark sense of honor and...
body:
One of the things that I think game of thrones should be applauded for is how they presented the Stark sense of honor and loyalty as simultaneously being their greatest strength as well as their fatal flaw

Ok so by the end of the series, a good amount of starks are dead. And what killed them was their enemies, obviously, but also their sense of honor brought their fates upon them

You wanna know how of all the starks, Sansa and Arya survived (not including bran cause he wasn’t in as much danger or Jon because he actually did die)? They were the ones who were willing to bend that honor and ideology of the stark house in order to survive. Sansa lied and faked loyalty to the lannisters, their greatest enemy, because she knew that they would kill her if she didn’t. She even went as far to learn from the worst people she knew, littlefinger and Cersei. Ned, cat, Robb, Jon-none of the would’ve done that, their sense of honor wa too great. Arya learned to train and fight as an assassin to kill everyone on her list of names because that was what was keeping her will to live alive, vengeance. Again, no other stark would’ve been vengeful like that, but it was Arya’s trait, and it kept her going. Vengeance and dishonesty-two traits that are not what starks are known for. But what kept Sansa and Arya alive in their respective positions was special to both of them. If Sansa had been in Arya’s situation, she would have died very fast, and if Arya had been in sansa’s, she wouldn’t have made it beyond season 2, because neither of them were designed for the other’s circumstances. Granted, no one is really designed for what Sansa went through, but she did because she endured. Jon Snow could’ve never lied like that. Sansa has said herself that she is a terrible liar. But here’s the thing. She lied convincingly enough to stay alive and not be murdered to send a message. She lied convincingly for Littlefinger because she knew it would keep her alive. Sansa adapted better than almost anyone would, and she sacrificed honor and honesty because how else would she stay alive long enough to regain them? No starks were ruthless and terrifying or murderous in the series beginning. But that’s what Arya became. She had to become that to survive, to complete her list. She can fight better than almost anyone now, able to match brienne with her immense speed and agility. Arya didn’t kill the night king for nothing. She was absolutely terrifying after murdering House frey, and she was terrifying once more when she threatened Sansa with wearing her face. Arya and Sansa managed to survive because they bent the stark ideals, but also because their experience in the word had made them smarter and harder. They were now much more suspicious of people, of everyone, than Jon Snow ever was. They didn’t trust dany, and rightfully so; look what happened to king’s landing in season eight. The stark sisters survived because they knew to think with their minds, not with their honor or House loyalty.

The starks who died died because their enemies took their greatest strength-honor-and turned it against them, into their detrimental flaw. Robb and Catelyn died honoring the wishes of someone they had wronged, but he hadn’t forgiven them. Robb thought with his heart instead of his mind when he got married, and it got him stabbed. Ned retained his honor to Robert and the other Baratheons as the true heirs to the throne, and when trying to expose the truth, he was murdered. Jon believed in honor and honesty just like the man who raised him. He honored the wishes of the wildlings, and the others killed him for it. Even later, the reason why Cersei’s army doesn’t fight in the long night is because he couldn’t feasibly lie to her about his allegiances. Arya and Sansa would’ve lied in an instant, and even Tyrion and dany call him out on it.

If any dead starks (plus Jon) had been in sansas situation, they wouldn’t have survived because the dishonesty of it all would’ve been too great for them. If they had been in Arya’s situation, they would not have been able to stand the dishonor of traveling with thieves and lowborns and learning to fight from a man who wears other people’s faces.

The stark ideals are good ones, but in a world as bad as the GOT universe, people would use it against them, and it would be the catalyst of their eventual downfall. The ability to fight and murder for vengeance and survival reasons, and the ability to read peoples intentions and lie and forgo loyalty in the face of imminent death is what keeps people alive in a world as bad as GOT. Arya and Sansa developed those traits over the seasons, and it is what kept them alive over ned, cat, Robb, and, for a time, Jon
